Description: THE KACHEMAK BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE WAS DESIGNATED IN 1999 AND IS LOCATED IN HOMER, ALASKA. THE RESERVE IS ADMINISTERED BY THE ALASKA CENTER FOR CONSERVATION SCIENCE, UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE (UAA), WHO IS SUBMITTING THIS APPLICATION FOR THE FY23 FEDERAL BUDGET FOR FUNDS TO SUPPORT ADMINISTRATION, OPERATIONS, RESEARCH AND MONITORING, EDUCATION, COASTAL TRAINING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND COMMUNITY COUNCIL ACTIVITIES FROM JULY 1, 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2024. UAA IS REQUESTING $867,113, WHICH WILL BE MATCHED BY A TOTAL OF $371,620 FROM UAA.

THE HE'EIA NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (NERR), KANEOHE HI WAS DESIGNATED ON JANUARY 19, 2017. WITH PASSAGE OF THE COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1972, THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALLY RECOGNIZED THE NATIONAL SIGNIFICANCE OF COASTAL RESOURCES AND AUTHORIZED THE NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE SYSTEM (NERRS) ADMINISTERED BY NOAA. THE HE`EIA NERR WAS THE 29TH SITE TO BE DESIGNATED AS PART OF THE NERRS, BUT THE FIRST DESIGNED TO BE AN "INDIGENOUS AND COMMUNITY CONSERVED AREA" (ICCA). THE NERRS WORKS WITH EXISTING FEDERAL AND STATE AUTHORITIES TO ESTABLISH AND OPERATE RESEARCH RESERVES AND PROVIDE FOR THEIR LONG-TERM STEWARDSHIP. THE STATE OF HAWAI'I HAS DESIGNATED THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI'I, HAWAI'I INSTITUTE OF MARINE BIOLOGY (HIMB) AS THE LEAD STATE AGENCY FOR THE RESERVE. THE HE`EIA NERR MANAGEMENT PLAN DESCRIBES IN DETAIL THE RESERVE PROGRAMS AND OPERATIONS DURING THE FIVE-YEAR PERIOD EXTENDING FROM JULY 2022 TO DECEMBER 2026. THIS PROPOSAL IS BASED UPON T

THE SOUTH SLOUGH NERR WAS DESIGNATED IN 1974 AND IS IN OREGON. THE RESERVE IS ADMINISTERED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE LANDS (DSL) WHO IS SUBMITTING THIS APPLICATION FOR FY 23 FUNDS TO SUPPORT OPERATIONS, RESEARCH AND MONITORING, EDUCATION, TRAINING AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES FROM JULY 1, 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2024. DSL IS REQUESTING $1,017,113 WHICH WILL BE MATCHED BY $435,905 EXPENDED BY DSL IN THE FORM OF SALARIES AND OTHER PAYROLL EXPENSE AS WELL AS OPERATIONAL SERVICES AND SUPPLIES.

NYSDEC IS REQUESTING $771,474 WHICH WILL BE MATCHED BY $330,632 FROM STATE FUNDS IN THE FORM OF ANNUAL SALARY FOR THE RESERVE MANAGER AND CONTRACTUAL FUNDS FOR THE RESERVE PROGRAM COORDINATOR. THIS FY 2023 PROJECT WILL COMPLEMENT THE WORK ALREADY COMPLETED AND TO SOLIDIFY OPERATIONS AT THE NEW MONIE BAY FIELD STATION SITE. KEY OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) IMPROVE SITE SAFETY AND EFFICIENCY OF WATERBORNE OPERATIONS BY PROCURING A NEW YAMAHA 90HP 4 STROKE OUTBOARD MOTOR SYSTEM FOR RESERVE VESSEL, AND REPLACING THE CONTROLS AND FUEL SYSTEM; 2) CONTINUE SITE ENHANCEMENT BY DEMOLISHING THE EXISTING FARMHOUSE AND REMEDIATING THE SITE; 3) CONSTRUCT A COVER TO PROTECT THE EXISTING MOBILE DORM UNIT; AND 4) MAINTAIN FACILITIES DURING DEMOLITION AND SITE ENHANCEMENT BY PROVIDING ADA  ACCESSIBLE PORTABLE TOILETS ONSITE.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS INTENDED TO: 1) REPLACE AGING AND INCREASINGLY VULNERABLE TRAIL INFRASTRUCTURE ON THE WESTERN END OF THE SAPELO ISLAND NERR NATURE TRAIL BY REPLACING ONE BOARDWALK, AND CONSTRUCTING TWO NEW BOARDWALKS THROUGH THE MARSH, ONE OF WHICH WILL FEATURE A NEW EDUCATION PAVILION; 2) RESTORE SALTMARSH VEGETATION IN THE FOOTPRINT OF THE FORMER EDUCATION PAVILION AND ACCESS BOARDWALK; 3) FACILITATE FUTURE REMOVAL OF AN INCREASINGLY DYSFUNCTIONAL EARTHEN CAUSEWAY THROUGH THE MARSH AND A LARGER SALTMARSH RESTORATION OF THE CAUSEWAY FOOTPRINT. THE EARTHEN CAUSEWAY IS THE SOLE TRAIL INFRASTRUCTURE RUNNING THROUGH SALTMARSH AND CONNECTING THE TRAILHEAD TO THE REST OF THE NATURE TRAIL EAST OF DEAN CREEK. SPRING TIDES AND STORM FLOOD EVENTS LIMIT ACCESS ALONG THE CAUSEWAY AND DEGRADE TRAIL CONDITIONS, SOMETIMES UP TO SEVERAL DAYS AFTER A FLOODING EVENT. THESE CONDITIONS PRESENT CHALLENGES TO THE RESERVE'S EDUCATION AND RESEARCH STAFF, WHO RELY ON THE TRAIL AND CAUSEWAY FOR REGULAR

THE WELLS NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (WELLS RESERVE OR RESERVE) WAS DESIGNATED IN 1984 AND IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTH COAST OF MAINE. THE RESERVE IS ADMINISTERED BY THE WELLS NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY (RMA), WHICH IS SUBMITTING THIS APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2023 FUNDS TO SUPPORT OPERATIONS AND MANAGEMENT, RESEARCH, MONITORING, EDUCATION, TEACHER TRAINING, DECISION-MAKER TRAINING, SCIENCE COMMUNICATION, A DAVIDSON FELLOW, VOLUNTEER AND VISITOR SUPPORT, PROTECTED AREA STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES, AND EQUIPMENT PURCHASES. THE AWARD PERIOD WILL BE FROM JULY 1, 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2024. THE RMA IS REQUESTING $1,017,113.00 IN FEDERAL FUNDS, WHICH WILL BE MATCHED BY $398,091.00 IN NON-FEDERAL FUNDS FOR TOTAL PROJECT COSTS OF $1,415,204.00.

THE TIJUANA RIVER NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (TRNERR) WAS DESIGNATED IN 1982 AND IS LOCATED IN IMPERIAL BEACH, CALIFORNIA. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION IS TRNERR'S FEDERALLY DESIGNATED ADMINISTRATIVE LEAD AGENCY. THE SOUTHWEST WETLANDS INTERPRETIVE ASSOCIATION (SWIA) IS A 501C3 NON-PROFIT FOUNDATION WORKING WITH CALIFORNIA STATE PARKS TO CARRY OUT THE RESERVE'S RESEARCH AND MONITORING PROGRAMS THROUGH THIS GRANT. THE TASKS BELOW SUPPORT IDENTIFYING AND PRIORITIZING COASTAL MANAGEMENT ISSUES THAT CAN BE ADDRESSED BY THE TIJUANA RIVER NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE AND NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE SYSTEM. ALL TASKS CARRIED OUT BY SWIA AND ITS EMPLOYEES UNDER NOAA GRANT FUNDS ARE OVERSEEN BY THE RESERVE MANAGER AND WILL BE FULLY INTEGRATED WITH THOSE CALIFORNIA STATE PARKS (CSP) TASKS, SO AS TO PROVIDE FOR SEAMLESS RESERVE OPERATION AND ARE COVERED UNDER A 2011 MOU BETWEEN CSP AND SWIA. IN FY23, THESE FUNDS WILL SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RESERVE'S RESEARCH, MONITORING, TRAINING, AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS AS WELL AS BASIC OPERATIONS OF THE RESERVE. FEDERAL FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT KEY STAFF POSITIONS RESEARCH COORDINATOR, EDUCATION COORDINATOR, CTP COORDINATOR, STEWARDSHIP COORDINATOR, SWMP TECHNICIAN, AND SEASONAL RESEARCH STAFF. THE SWMP STATION LOCATED AT POINT AUX CHENES (FIGURE 1) WAS COMPLETELY LOST DURING HURRICANE SALLY INCLUDING THE SONDE AND ALL SUPPORTING INFRASTRUCTURE INCLUDING ATTACHMENTS, SONDE TUBE, AND PILING. BY LOSING THIS STATION WE LOST ALL CAPABILITIES TO COLLECT WATER QUALITY DATA AT THAT LOCATION. THE EQUIPMENT WILL BE REPLACED WITH THESE FUNDS. A DETAILED DESCRIPTION OF THE REPLACEMENT OF THE SONDE INCLUDES THE PURCHASE OF A NEW SONDE TO REPLACE THE ONE THAT WAS LOST. THE REPLACEMENT OF THIS SONDE IS IDENTIFIED IN NOAA FY22 DISASTER RELIEF APPROPRIATIONS SPEND PLAN, AND THE MAPPED LOCATION IS REFERENCED ABOVE AS FIGURE 1 WHICH IS WHERE THE REPLACEMENT SONDE WILL BE DEPLOYED.

FUNDS ARE SOUGHT TO REPAIR OR REPLACE INFRASTRUCTURE AT WEEKS BAY NERR DAMAGED BY HURRICANE SALLY IN 2020. THESE DAMAGES WERE NOT COVERED UNDER THE ALABAMA DIVISION OF RISK MANAGEMENT PROPERTY INSURANCE, FEMA OR OTHER STATE OR FEDERAL FUNDING SOURCES. THIS INCLUDES REPAIRS TO THE DAMAGED KITCHEN FACILITY AT THE SAFE HARBOR PROPERTY, REPAIRS TO THE RESERVE NATURE TRAIL BOARDWALK AND OVERLOOK, AND REPLACEMENT OF OBSERVATIONAL (MONITORING) INFRASTRUCTURE. TO MINIMIZE RESIDUAL DAMAGE TO RESERVE FACILITIES AND ENSURE VISITOR SAFETY, DAMAGED AND DEAD TREES WILL BE REMOVED FROM AROUND THE VISITOR CENTER CAMPUS, VISITOR CENTER BOARDWALK AND NATURE TRAIL BY A PROFESSIONAL TREE SERVICE.

THE HAWAI'I INSTITUTE OF MARINE BIOLOGY (HIMB), BASED IN THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI'I AT MANOA'S SCHOOL OF OCEAN AND EARTH SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY, OCCUPIES MOKU O LO'E, A 28-ACRE ISLET IN KANE'OHE BAY, LOCATED ON THE NORTH-EASTERN SIDE OF O'AHU. SINCE THE LAKE SUPERIOR NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE WAS DESIGNATED IN 2010, WE HAVE INCREASED IN STAFF SIZE AND CAPACITY AS WE STRIVE TOWARDS OUR MISSION AND STRENGTHEN OUR PARTNERSHIPS. AS A RESULT, AVAILABLE OFFICE SPACE FOR RESERVE STAFF AND KEY PARTNERS WHO SHARE OUR FACILITY IS BECOMING INCREASINGLY LIMITED. OUR OFFICE AND LABORATORY SPACE IN SUPERIOR, WISCONSIN CURRENTLY HOUSES SIX ENCLOSED OFFICES FOR EIGHT FULL-TIME RESERVE STAFF AND TWO WISCONSIN SEA GRANT STAFF. AN ADDITIONAL FIVE STAFF ARE IMMEDIATELY IN NEED OF OFFICE SPACE, WHILE PLANNED FUTURE STAFFING ADDITIONS ARE EXPECTED TO REQUIRE AN ADDITIONAL FIVE OFFICES OVER THE NEXT TEN YEARS. EXTENSION EMPLOYEES ARE REQUIRED TO WORK AT THEIR OFFICES AT MINIMUM THREE DAYS PER WEEK AND TELECOMMUTING DOES NOT PROVIDE A VIABLE SOLUTION FOR THE LARGELY PLACE-BASED WORK OF THE RESERVE.  RENOVATIONS TO THE CURRENT OFFICE BUILDING COULD SIGNIFICANTLY EXPAND AVAILABLE SPACES TO MEET THIS NEED WHILE REDUCING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPAC

THE GOALS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO 1) ELIMINATE UTILITY INFRASTRUCTURE FROM SENSITIVE SALT MARSH HABITAT, AND 2) INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF THE NBNERR AND PRUDENCE ISLAND COMMUNITY TO COASTAL HAZARDS AND OTHER IMPACTS BY REDUCING ABOVEGROUND UTILITY INFRASTRUCTURE IN A VULNERABLE LOCATION. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO: 1. RELOCATE ELECTRIC UTILITY WIRES THAT CURRENTLY CROSS NAG MARSH UNDERGROUND ALONG NECK FARM ROAD 2. REMOVE 7 UTILITY POLES FROM NAG MARSH WE ANTICIPATE THAT ALL OBJECTIVES WILL BE COMPLETED WITHIN YEAR 1 OF THE PROJECT. THIS IS REALISTIC GIVEN THAT WORK WILL BE PERFORMED BY UTILITY COMPANY NATIONAL GRID, WHO WILL HANDLE ALL ASPECTS OF PERMITTING AND CONSTRUCTION, OBVIATING THE NEED TO GO THROUGH ADDITIONAL PROCUREMENT PROCESSES.

THIS PROJECT IS STRAIGHT-FORWARD: WITH CLIMATE CHANGE PREDICTED TO EXACERBATE STORM FREQUENCY AND INTENSITY IN THE NORTHEAST, THE RESERVE SEEKS TO SECURE ITS RESEARCH AND EDUCATION/PUBLIC PROGRAM RESOURCES WITH THE INVESTMENT OF GENERATED (BACKUP) POWER. OUR ABILITY TO BROADEN AND STRENGTHEN OUR BACKUP POWER RESOURCES THROUGH STANDBY GENERATORS FOR TWO BUILDINGS, AND READYING ANOTHER TO EASILY ACCEPT A PORTABLE GENERATOR, ARE ESSENTIAL TO FUNCTIONING AS AN EFFECTIVE AND RESILIENT RESERVE IN THE NERR SYSTEM. THESE RETROFITS AND INFRASTRUCTURE ENHANCEMENTS WILL ALLOW THE WELLS RESERVE'S BUILDINGS TO CONTINUE TO OPERATE DURING POWER OUTAGES; WE DO NOT WANT TO LOSE VALUABLE, ONGOING SCIENTIFIC EXPERIMENTS OR CANCEL PUBLIC AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. THE BARN AND THE MCEC ARE SHELTERS FOR STAFF AND VISITORS TO MOVE TO DURING STORMS, OUTAGES, AND EMERGENCIES; HAVING POWER TO THESE BUILDINGS BECOMES EVEN MORE IMPERATIVE. THE ROOKERY BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE RECEIVED OWNERSHIP OF THE BRIGGS BOARDWALK FROM THE CONSERVANCY OF SOUTHWEST FLORIDA IN DECEMBER OF 2020. THIS GRANT APPLICATION WOULD FUND THE DEMOLITION AND RE-BUILDING OF A MORE RESILIENT AND INCLUSIVE BOARDWALK TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO THE COMMUNITY. THE RESERVE ANTICIPATES A THREE-YEAR PROJECT FOR PERMIT, DEMOLITION AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE BOARDWALK. THE NEW STRUCTURE WILL BE FULLY ADA COMPLIANT AND HAVE INTERPRETATIVE SIGNAGE IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES TO MAKE IT ACCESSIBLE AND WELCOMING TO A DIVERSE AUDIENCE OF USERS. ADDITIONALLY, THE REBUILDING OF A MORE RESILIENT STRUCTURE TO SEA LEVEL RISE AND HURRICANES WILL ENSURE THE RESERVE'S EDUCATION STAFF AND VOLUNTEER DOCENTS WILL BE ABLE TO CONTINUE OFFERING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS USING THE BOARDWALK. THE GRANT IS KEY TO SECURING FUNDS TO PERMIT, DECONSTRUCT THE EXISTING BOARDWALK, AND RE-BUILD A NEW AND MORE RESILIENT BOARDWALK WITH INTERPRETIVE SIGNS.

THE JC NERR HAS EXPERIENCED SIGNIFICANT GROWTH IN THE PORTFOLIO OF PROGRAMS OFFERED TO A DIVERSE ARRAY OF COASTAL STAKEHOLDERS. LEVERAGED COMPETITIVE GRANT SUPPORT, AVERAGING BETWEEN $1-$2 MILLION ANNUALLY, HAS RESULTED IN DEVELOPMENT OF INNOVATIVE CORE PROGRAMS THAT EXTENDED THE REACH OF THE RESERVE TO REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCALES, AND INCREASED THE USE OF THE JC NERR AS A SENTINEL SITE FOR RESEARCH PROJECTS. IN TURN, THIS SUCCESS HAS NECESSITATED THE ADDITION OF STAFF AND SPACE TO MEET THESE OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES. WE BEGAN TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS IN OUR PARTIALLY FUNDED PROCUREMENT, ACQUISITION, AND CONSTRUCTION FY 2020 GRANT WITH WHICH WE INITIATED A PHASED APPROACH TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A SUSTAINABLE AND RESILIENT JC NERR COASTAL CAMPUS. THIS REQUEST IS TO ACCOMMODATE THE CONSTRUCTION ITEMS FROM THE FY2020 GRANT THAT COULD NOT BE FUNDED DUE TO RISING COSTS IN LABOR AND SUPPLIES RELATED TO THE COVID PANDEMIC, SUPPLY CHAIN ISSUES, AND NEW CODE REQUIREMENTS THAT MANDATE A

FUNDS ARE SOUGHT TO REPLACE APPROXIMATELY 1,300 LINEAR FEET AND REMOVE APPROXIMATELY 1,400 LINEAR FEET OF AGED AND STORM DAMAGED BOARDWALK ADJACENT THE WEEKS BAY NERR VISITOR CENTER. FUNDS ARE ALSO SOUGHT TO INSTALL STORM RESILIENT INTERPRETIVE SIGNS UPON AND ADJACENT TO THE REPLACED BOARDWALK AND PLANT NATIVE FLORA ADJACENT TO BOARDWALK FOR EDUCATIONAL AND AESTHETIC PURPOSE.  THE CURRENT BOARDWALK WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1993 AND TRAVERSES A MIX OF HABITATS BETWEEN THE VISITOR CENTER AND WEEKS BAY ESTUARY. THE BOARDWALK PROVIDES RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES SUCH AS HIKING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, AND PHOTOGRAPHY TO THE PUBLIC WHILE PROTECTING SENSITIVE AND RARE ECOSYSTEMS FROM DISTURBANCE AND INTENSE FOOT TRAFFIC. THE BOARDWALK IS USED BY RESERVE STAFF TO HOST EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING PROGRAMS AND HAS ALSO BEEN EMPLOYED BY VISITING RESEARCHERS AND STAFF TO ACCESS TEST PLOTS AND TRANSECTS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE AND REPURPOSE THE GLENN COVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA TO ENHANCE PUBLIC ACCESS ALONG GREAT BAY AND PROVIDE SPACE AND INFRASTRUCTURE FOR EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMMING. OVER $700,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDS, MATCHED BY OVER $300,000 IN RECIPIENT FUNDS, WILL BE USED TO INCREASE PUBLIC AND PARTNER USE OF THE GREAT BAY RESERVE THROUGH THE CONSTRUCTION OF A PUBLIC PAVILION WITH RESTROOM FACILITIES, PARKING AREAS, AND EDUCATIONAL KIOSKS AND EXHIBITS INTERPRETING THE HISTORY AND UNIQUE FEATURES OF THE RESERVE SITE.

THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THREEFOLD: 1) TO IMPROVE THE VEHICULAR ENTRY POINT TO IONA ISLAND MARSH, 2) TO PROVIDE ADA-COMPLIANT ACCESS TO THE MARSH EDGE AND 3) TO DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE AND RESILIENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR RECREATION AND EDUCATION AT IONA ISLAND MARSH.

THE JOBOS BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (JBNERR) WAS DESIGNATED IN 1981 AS PART OF THE NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE SYSTEM (NERRS), ESTABLISHED BY SECTION 315 OF THE COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT ACT, AS AMENDED. JBNERR IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHEAST COAST OF THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO, BETWEEN THE MUNICIPALITIES OF SALINAS AND GUAYAMA. THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL ADMINISTERS THE RESERVE AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (PRDNER), WHICH IS SUBMITTING THIS MULTI-YEAR APPLICATION FOR FY2022 AND FY2023 FUNDS TO SUPPORT OPERATIONS, RESEARCH AND MONITORING, EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES FROM OCTOBER 1, 2022 THROUGH MARCH 31, 2025. IN FY22, THE PRDNER IS PLANNING FOR $780,500 IN FEDERAL FUNDING WHICH WILL BE MATCHED WITH $327,354. STAFF AND ADMINISTRATIVE SALARY AND CONTRACTS PROVIDE NON-FEDERAL MATCH. IN FY23, THE PRDNER IS ESTIMATING $850,745.00 IN FEDERAL FUNDING, WHICH WILL BE MATCHED FROM THE PRDNER WITH THE $299,153.00 IN NON-FEDERAL FUNDS.

EELGRASS BEDS ARE KNOWN TO BE IMPORTANT HABITATS, PROVIDING FOOD AND PROTECTION FOR MANY SPECIES OF JUVENILE FISH. SUCCESSFUL FORAGING WITHIN BEDS IS CRITICAL FOR JUVENILES TO SURVIVE AN IMPORTANT LIFE HISTORY BOTTLENECK AND REACH ADULTHOOD. INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF NUTRIENT ENRICHMENT AND WAVE ENERGY ON PLANT COMMUNITY STRUCTURE AND  ECOSYSTEM STABILITY  WEEKS BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE  EUTROPHICATION IS A COMMON PROBLEM IN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS THROUGHOUT THE WORLD. NUTRIENT ENRICHMENT FROM ANTHROPOGENIC SOURCES IN WATERSHEDS CAN LEAD TO HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS, CHANGES IN AQUATIC FOOD WEBS, AND ECOSYSTEM COLLAPSE. THE WEEKS BAY ESTUARY IN BALDWIN COUNTY, ALABAMA IS CONSIDERED A EUTROPHIC ESTUARY, AND RECENT INCREASES IN NUTRIENT LOADING HAVE COINCIDED WITH TIDAL MARSH LOSS WITHIN THE WEEKS BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (NERR). AS SUCH, GAINING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF EUTROPHICATION ON WETLAND LOSS IS OF SPECIFIC CONCERN TO MANAGERS AND STAKEHOLDERS AT THE RESERVE. DIFFERENT NUTRIENTS AFFECT MARSH STABILITY AND LOSS IN DIFFERENT WAYS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW VEGETATION RECOLONIZES IN A SALT MARSH THAT IS RESTORED IN ANTICIPATION OF FUTURE SEA-LEVEL RISE. CURRENTLY, THE STAFF AND RESEARCHERS AT ELKHORN SLOUGH ARE UNDERTAKING A RESTORATION PROJECT (HESTER MARSH) THAT IS BOTH RESTORING A DEGRADE SALT MARSH AND EXPANDING IT IN SIZE AND HEIGHT TO TAKE INTO ACCOUNT FUTURE SEA-LEVEL RISE. THREE YEARS HAVE PASSED SINCE THE COMPLETION OF THE FIRST PHASE; HOWEVER, RECOLONIZATION OF IMPORTANT PLANT SPECIES HAS BEEN PATCHY AND HAS BECOME A PRIORITY MANAGEMENT NEED. THIS RESTORATION METHOD IS NOVEL IN ITS ATTEMPT TO USE MORE SEDIMENT THAN TRADITIONAL SEDIMENT ADDITION RESTORATION METHODS AND HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE IMPORTANT FOR SHAPING FUTURE RESTORATION PRACTICES ACROSS THE WEST COAST. THEREFORE, UNDERSTANDING BARRIERS TO SUCCESS AND IMPROVING RESTORATION DESIGN IS IMPORTANT TO HELP OTHERS ATTEMPTING SIMILAR METHODS. POPULATIONS OF THE EASTERN OYSTER HAVE DRAMATICALLY DECLINED IN THESE REGIONS AS A RESULT OF OVERHARVESTING AND DISEASE, AMONG OTHER FACTORS. FOR MANAGEMENT OF THESE ESTUARINE RESOURCES IN THE FUTURE, IT IS CRITICAL TO INVESTIGATE FACTORS THAT CURRENTLY EFFECT OYSTER DEMOGRAPHICS AND DISTRIBUTION AND UNDERSTAND HOW THOSE FACTORS MAY CHANGE IN THE FUTURE. THE SAPELO ISLAND NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE PROVIDES A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO ADDRESS HOW CHANGING WATER QUALITY MIGHT AFFECT OYSTER DEMOGRAPHICS. COASTAL WETLANDS ARE VULNERABLE TO SEA LEVEL RISE. PLANT COMMUNITIES ARE ALREADY SHIFTING AS WETLANDS MIGRATE INLAND BECAUSE OF INCREASED FLOODING AND SALINITY. TO PROTECT WETLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS TO COASTAL COMMUNITIES, THE CHESAPEAKE BAY MARYLAND  NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVES (CBNERR-MD) REQUIRES A DEEP UNDERSTANDING OF CHANGING WETLAND CONDITIONS AND MARSH MIGRATION PATTERNS. TO BEST ADDRESS CBNERR-MD'S COASTAL MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES, THIS PROJECT HAS TWO COMPONENTS: 1. STATISTICAL MODELING OF VEGETATION SHIFTS AS A FUNCTION OF CHANGES IN ELEVATION AND SALINITY 2. A FIELD STUDY OF MICROBIOME AND SOIL CARBON INDICATORS OF VEGETATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL SHIFTS CHARACTERIZED IN THE VEGETATION MODELING.

BIOINDICATORS ARE ORGANISMS THAT REFLECT OR RECORD THE CONDITIONS WITHIN AN ENVIRONMENT, DISPLAYED AS ABUNDANCE, ASSEMBLAGE STRUCTURE, OR FUNCTION OF THE ORGANISMS LIVING IN THAT ENVIRONMENT. BIOINDICATORS CAN BE USED TO DETECT POLLUTION AND PROVIDE A QUANTIFIABLE METRIC OF THE HEALTH OF THE ECOSYSTEM THEY INHABIT. RECENT WORK WITH UPSIDE-DOWN JELLIES (CASSIOPEA) HAS REVEALED THEIR VERSATILITY AS BIOINDICATORS IN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS, RESPONDING TO TRACE METALS, HERBICIDES, AND NUTRIENT INPUT. RECENT STUDIES HAVE PROPOSED THE USE OF CASSIOPEA AS PROSPECTIVE BIOINDICATORS FOR DETECTING NUTRIENT POLLUTION, AS THEIR SYMBIONTS THRIVE ON THE ABRUPT NUTRIENT AVAILABILITY. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON THE QUESTION: CAN UPSIDE-DOWN JELLIES BE USED AS BIOINDICATORS OF NUTRIENT POLLUTION OR OTHER ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES IN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS? COASTAL WETLANDS PROVIDE NUMEROUS ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, BUT THEY FACE INCREASING THREATS IN LATERAL AND VERTICAL DIMENSIONS FROM EROSIVE FORCES AND SEA-LEVEL RISE, RESPECTIVELY. WETLAND RESPONSES TO THESE STRESSORS VARY REGIONALLY AND FOLLOWING CERTAIN SITE-SPECIFIC CHARACTERISTICS LIKE SUSPENDED SEDIMENT CONCENTRATION AND UPLAND MIGRATION POTENTIAL. UNDERSTANDING HOW RESPONSES WILL CHANGE WITH HIGHER SEA-LEVEL RISE RATES IS CRITICAL FOR MAKING INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS NOW TO MINIMIZE WETLAND LOSS. BECAUSE COASTAL WETLANDS BORDERING THE CHESAPEAKE BAY ARE EXPERIENCING THE HIGHEST SLR RATES ON THE EASTERN UNITED STATES COAST, THEY MAKE FOR PRESCIENT STUDY SITES AND MAY EXPERIENCE MINIMAL LOSS WITH URGENT RESTORATION ACTION. THIS PROJECT WILL ANSWER THREE MANAGEMENT NEEDS ISSUED BY THE CHESAPEAKE BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE IN VIRGINIA (CBNERR-VA): (1) SYNTHESES OF LONG-TERM DATA TO AID IN (2) AN INVESTIGATION OF TIDAL WETLAND VULNERABILITY AND (3) TESTING OF RESTORATION

CLIMATE CHANGE MEDIATED OCEAN ACIDIFICATION (OA) HAS NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON MARINE ECOSYSTEMS, E.G., CORAL REEFS, CALCIFYING ORGANISMS, ETC. HOWEVER, THE EFFECT OF OA IN ESTUARIES HAS NOT BEEN EXTENSIVELY STUDIED, PARTICULARLY WHEN COMPARING URBAN (DISTURBED) AND PRISTINE (UNDISTURBED) WATERSHEDS THAT FEED INTO THESE ESTUARIES. IT IS THOUGHT THAT LONG-TERM ATMOSPHERIC ACIDIFICATION PROCESSES (AS OPPOSED TO OA) FACILITATES WEATHERING AND PARADOXICALLY CAUSES AN INCREASE IN CARBONATE ALKALINE SPECIES (DONEY ET AL., 2009; ORR ET AL., 2005) AND DISSOLVED ORGANIC MATTER (DOM, ANOTHER BUFFER AGAINST ACIDIFICATION) IN ESTUARINE SYSTEMS (LONBORG ET AL., 2020). SIGNIFICANT EVIDENCE HAS SHOWN THAT WATERSHEDS (ESPECIALLY URBAN IMPACTED ONES) RELEASE MORE ALKALINE SPECIES AND DOM (KUSHAL ET AL., 2013; TANG ET AL., 2019). THEREFORE, MY OBJECTIVE IS TO STUDY THE EFFECTS OF OA IN MID-ATLANTIC ESTUARIES AND HOW THIS MAY BE COUNTERBALANCED BY AN INCREASE IN THE ACID NEUTRALIZATION CAPACITY (ANC) OF STRE

SHELLFISH HARVESTING HAS HISTORICALLY BEEN A MAJOR PART OF THE LOCAL ECONOMY; HOWEVER, DUE TO HIGH FECAL COLIFORM COUNTS THE GRAND BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (GNDNERR) HAS BEEN CLOSED SINCE 2007. FECAL COLIFORMS ARE NOT HARMFUL; HOWEVER, THEY CAN INDICATE THE PRESENCE OF PATHOGENS THAT COULD BE HARMFUL TO HUMANS. THE GNDNERR HAS DETERMINED THAT MICROBIAL SOURCE TRACKING IS A PRIORITY MANAGEMENT NEED, SO THAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS CAN BE IDENTIFIED AND HARVESTING POTENTIALLY REOPENED. THE MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF MARINE RESOURCES (MDMR; STATE PARTNER OF THE GNDNERR) SUSPECTS THAT THE TWO HIGHEST FECAL LOADS ARE COMING FROM HUMANS AND FERAL HOGS, WHICH INHERENTLY HAVE DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MITIGATE THEIR IMPACTS. IN ORDER TO DETERMINE THE HOST OF THE FECAL COLIFORMS, WATER SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED EVERY MONTH FOR TWO YEARS DURING RANDOM WEATHER EVENTS; THESE SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED ALONGSIDE FECAL COLIFORM SAMPLE COLLECTION WITH MDMR TO BETTER CORRELATE COLIFORM

THE AMERICAN LOBSTER INDUSTRY IS ONE OF THE MOST VALUABLE FISHERIES IN THE U.S., AND AS OTHER FISHERIES IN THE REGION HAVE STRUGGLED, NEW ENGLAND'S DEPENDENCE ON LOBSTERS HAS GROWN DUE TO A SURGE IN POPULATIONS AND LANDINGS OVER THE PAST THREE DECADES.  AMERICAN LOBSTER ACCOUNTS FOR A LARGE PROPORTION OF THE ECONOMIC VALUE OF FISHERIES LANDED IN THE GULF OF MAINE (GOM). UNFORTUNATELY, THE LOBSTER FISHERY IS ALREADY BEING IMPACTED BY THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN PART DUE TO NOVEL, RANGE-EXPANDING SPECIES SUCH AS BLACK SEA BASS AND BLUE CRABS ENTERING SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND AND THE GOM. YET, IT IS UNCLEAR ABOUT THESE SPECIES' DISTRIBUTIONS IN THEIR NEWLY EXPANDED RANGES, AND THEIR INTERACTIONS WITH NATIVE GOM SPECIES LIKE AMERICAN LOBSTER. IT IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTAND WHICH HABITATS RANGE-EXPANDING SPECIES ARE OCCUPYING AND WHETHER THEY OVERLAP WITH AND CONSUME CRITICAL LIFE-HISTORY STAGES OF AMERICAN LOBSTER SUCH AS JUVENILES. THIS PROJECT SERVES TO ANSWER THESE QUESTIONS AND EVALUATE

NATURALLY OCCURRING DISSOLVED ORGANIC MATTER WITHIN AQUATIC SYSTEMS PLAYS A CRITICAL ROLE IN THE BIOGEOCHEMICAL CYCLING OF CARBON AND NUTRIENTS, BOTH AS A SOURCE FOR BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTION AND AS ONE OF THE LARGEST ACTIVE CARBON RESERVOIRS ON EARTH. WHETHER FROM A NATURAL OR HUMAN-DERIVED SOURCE, EXCESSIVE DISSOLVED ORGANIC MATTER CAN LEAD TO ENVIRONMENTAL DISTRESS WITHIN THE LOCALIZED AREA OF INPUT BY IMPAIRING DOWNSTREAM WATER QUALITY VIA EUTROPHICATION AND DISSOLVED OXYGEN CONSUMPTION, AND AT A LARGER SCALE, CONTRIBUTE TO INCREASED CARBON DIOXIDE IN THE ATMOSPHERE. LIMITED STUDIES HAVE BEEN COMPLETED REGARDING AQUATIC DISSOLVED ORGANIC MATTER FROM NON-POINT SOURCES AND HOW IT IS CYCLED AND TRANSFORMED AS IT TRAVELS THROUGH AQUATIC SYSTEMS AND INTO THE COASTAL OCEAN, ESPECIALLY BLACKWATER ECOSYSTEMS LIKE THE WINYAH BAY WATERSHED. TO ADDRESS THESE GAPS, THE FATE OF DISSOLVED ORGANIC MATTER WITH RESPECT TO SOURCE AND COMPOSITION MUST BE ANALYZED ON SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. TO BETTER

SEAGRASS BEDS ARE FOUNDATION SPECIES THAT DEFINE AND SUPPORT COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS GLOBALLY, YET THEIR PERSISTENCE IS THREATENED BY HUMAN-INDUCED CLIMATE CHANGE AND DISTURBANCES. SEAGRASS DIE-OFFS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED ECOLOGICAL CONSEQUENCES ARE INCREASINGLY OBSERVED ALONG THE WEST COAST OF THE US, INCLUDING OREGON. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO CHARACTERIZE THE SEED BANKS AND SEDIMENTS OF Z. MARINA BEDS IN SOUTH SLOUGH AND NEARBY SITES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE NATURAL RECOVERY POTENTIAL OF EELGRASS AFTER A SUBSTANTIAL, RECENTLY DOCUMENTED DIE-OFF. I WILL ALSO INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS OF INNATE AND EXTERNAL FACTORS ON Z. MARINA SEED AND SEEDLING RESISTANCE TO THERMAL STRESS UNDER PREDICTED WARMING DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE.  THE SEED BANK SAMPLING EFFORT WILL PRODUCE DATA CHARACTERIZING 1) Z. MARINA SEED BANKS - SEED, REPRODUCTIVE SHOOT, AND SEEDLING DENSITY, AND PERCENT VIABILITY; AND 2) SEDIMENTS - GRANULOMETRY, ORGANIC MATTER CONTENT, SULFIDE CONCENTRATION, AND WATER TEMPERATURE.

THE ACE BASIN NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE'S (NERR) MCKENZIE FIELD STATION, LOCATED IN THE REMOTE FISHING COMMUNITY OF BENNETT'S POINT, SOUTH CAROLINA, IS INVALUABLE TO THE ACE BASIN NERR, OUR PARTNERS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE COMMUNITY. THE FIELD STATION PROVIDES OFFICE SPACE FOR NERR STEWARDSHIP AND ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF, DORMS FOR VISITING RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, AND PARTNERS, INDOOR AND OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS, A LABORATORY, THE RESERVE'S METEOROLOGICAL STATION, AND A DOCK THAT CAN ACCOMMODATE SEVERAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION VESSELS AT A TIME. THE FIELD STATION SERVES AS THE "GATEWAY TO THE ACE BASIN" AS ONE OF THE ONLY PUBLIC FACILITIES IN THE HEART OF THE RESERVE. THE STATION IS A CORE FACILITY THAT IS CRITICAL TO THE RESERVE'S MISSION, AND THE RESERVE
OPERATES WITH A MANDATE TO PROVIDE THIS FACILITY AND ITS ASSOCIATED SERVICES. THE FATE OF THIS FACILITY AND ITS ASSOCIATED ASSETS INCLUDING THE DOCK ARE THREATENED BY SEVERE AND ONGOING SHORELINE EROSION ALONG THE ENTIRE LENGTH OF THE PROPERTY ADJACENT TO MOSQUITO CREEK.
THE SHORELINE EROSION IS A RESULT OF GEOMORPHOLOGY AND IS EXACERBATED BY SEA LEVEL RISE. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE SHORELINE EROSION THROUGH A SHORELINE STABILIZATION PROJECT THAT UTILIZES A HYBRID APPROACH INCORPORATING BOTH TRADITIONAL EROSION CONTROL MEASURES AS WELL AS
NATURE-BASED ALTERNATIVES KNOWN AS LIVING SHORELINES. THIS HYBRID APPROACH WILL OFFER THE HIGHEST AND MOST LONG-TERM LEVEL OF PROTECTION OF CRITICAL ASSETS WHILE INCORPORATING HABITAT-IMPROVEMENT AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES. WE BELIEVE THAT THIS APPROACH WILL HELP TO ACHIEVE RESILIENCE OF THE STATION AND ITS INFRASTRUCTURE AND ASSETS, RESERVE PROGRAMMING, AS WELL AS NATURAL HABITATS ALONG THE SHORELINE. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE MCKENZIE FIELD STATION AND RELATED INFRASTRUCTURE AND ASSETS BY STABILIZING THE HIGHLY EROSIONAL SHORELINE FRONTAGE ALONG MOSQUITO CREEK. ULTIMATELY,
THE GOAL IS TO MAINTAIN THE SERVICES AND RESOURCES AVAILABLE TO STAFF, PARTNERS, AND THE PUBLIC IN THE ACE BASIN TO FURTHER THE RESERVE'S MISSION. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO
ACHIEVE SHORELINE STABILIZATION THROUGH A HYBRID APPROACH THAT BOTH PROTECTS CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SUPPORTS HABITATS AND BIODIVERSITY. AN ADDITIONAL OBJECTIVE IS FOR BOTH THE SHORELINE STABILIZATION CONSTRUCTION AS WELL AS ITS LONG-TERM PRESENCE AT THE FIELD STATION TO SERVE AS
EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES FOR A VARIETY OF AUDIENCES.
THE PRIMARY OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A STABILIZED SHORELINE ALONG MOSQUITO CREEK SPANNING THE MCKENZIE FIELD STATION PROPERTY. THE SHORELINE WILL PROTECT THE SIGNIFICANT INVESTMENTS INVOLVED AT THE MCKENZIE FIELD STATION SITE, AS WELL AS PRESERVE THE RESERVE'S ABILITY TO PERFORM ITS CORE RESEARCH, STEWARDSHIP, AND EDUCATION FUNCTIONS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN OUTREACH PRODUCTS INCLUDING INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE, TRAININGS, AND A LASTING DEMONSTRATION SITE. THIS
WILL RESULT IN AUDIENCES HAVING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF LIVING SHORELINES, PARTICULARLY NONTRADITIONAL APPROACHES, AND BEING BETTER PREPARED TO IMPLEMENT LIVING SHORELINES.

"KIPUKA" IS A HAWAIIAN WORD THAT DESCRIBES OASES OF VEGETATION SURROUNDED BY LAVA FLOWS, FROM WHICH SPREAD SEEDS THAT RE-START FOREST GROWTH.  THERE IS AN URGENT NEED FOR EDUCATIONAL KIPUKA: SAFE SPACES WHERE STUDENTS CAN CONTINUE LEARNING.  IN THE LONG-TERM, THIS INVESTMENT WILL CATALYZE GREATER ENGAGEMENT WITH THE EDUCATION COMMUNITY AND INCREASE CAPACITY TO DELIVER PROGRAMS.

THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS CAUSED UNPRECEDENTED DISRUPTION TO CLASSROOM-BASED EDUCATION.  IN DISTANCE-LEARNING SITUATIONS, K-12 STUDENTS AND TEACHERS FACE MAJOR CHALLENGES IN MAINTAINING ENGAGEMENT AND PHYSICAL, SOCIAL, AND MENTAL HEALTH.  SCHOOLS IN HAWAI I ARE BEGINNING TO REOPEN, BUT REDUCING STUDENT NUMBERS ON CAMPUSES WILL CONTINUE TO BE A STRATEGY FOR REDUCING DISEASE TRANSMISSION FOR THE FORESEEABLE FUTURE.

AT THE SAME TIME, INFORMAL AND OUTDOOR EDUCATION ORGANIZATIONS NATIONWIDE HAVE SEEN A STEEP DROP OFF IN PARTICIPATION AND REVENUE.  A STUDY PUBLISHED IN JUNE OF 2020 ESTIMATED THAT BY THE END OF THE YEAR, OVER ONE THIRD OF OUTDOOR EDUCATION PROVIDERS WOULD CEASE OPERATIONS, WITH THE IMPACTS DISPROPORTIONATELY FALLING ON COMMUNITIES OF COLOR (COLLINS ET AL. 2020).  THE EDUCATION PROGRAMS OF THE HE EIA NERR AND ITS PARTNERS SERVED MORE THAN 4,000 PREK-COLLEGE STUDENTS FROM JULY-DECEMBER 2019.  AN ADDITIONAL 2,000 STUDENTS VISITED IN EARLY 2020 PRIOR TO THE COMPLETE SHUTDOWN OF VISITOR PROGRAMS IN MARCH.  NEW INFRASTRUCTURE IS NEEDED FOR THE RESERVE TO CONTINUE TO OFFER SAFE, ON-SITE ESTUARINE AND SCIENCE EDUCATION PROGRAMS, INCLUDING THE TEACHERS ON THE ESTUARIES (TOTE) PROGRAM.
GIVEN THESE FACTORS, THE HE EIA NERR IS PROPOSING TO ASSIST KAKO O  OIWI TO ENHANCE THE FUNCTIONALITY OF FIVE OUTDOOR EDUCATION STRUCTURES (APPENDIX 1) AS KIPUKA TO SAFELY HOST PREK-COLLEGE STUDENT AND TEACHER GROUPS DURING THE PANDEMIC, THEREBY PRESERVING STUDENT ENGAGEMENT AND SOWING THE SEEDS FOR FUTURE RECOVERY AND REGROWTH.  THE STRUCTURES ARE ESSENTIALLY CLASSROOMS WITHOUT WALLS, PROVIDING A WELL-VENTILATED, YET SHELTERED SPACE WITH EASY ACCESS TO A CULTURALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY RICH SURROUNDING LEARNING ENVIRONMENT.  THE STRUCTURES ARE SUITED TO SMALL-GROUP INSTRUCTION, AND ARE DISPERSED OVER A WIDE AREA TO INCREASE BOTH SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY OF REMOTE PARTS OF THE RESERVE.

CULTURE AND "SENSE OF PLACE" ARE INTEGRAL TO HOW LEARNING ABOUT, INTERACT WITH, AND UNDERSTAND THE NATURAL WORLD. THIS PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON USING A CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE APPROACH TO FORGE NEW RELATIONSHIPS WITH PARTNERS AND CREATE NEW EDUCATIONAL DISPLAYS NECESSARY AT PADILLA BAY NERR TO IMPROVE THE VISITOR LEARNING EXPERIENCE AS IT RELATES TO CULTURAL REPRESENTATION, LANGUAGE ACCESSIBILITY, AND ARTISTIC EXPRESSION. IT IS RECOGNIZED THAT A WESTERN SCIENTIFIC PERSPECTIVE IS ONE OF MANY LENSES THROUGH WHICH WE ENGAGE IN LEARNING ABOUT THE NATURAL WORLD, AND THAT COLONIAL NARRATIVES CAN RUN STRONG IN DEPICTIONS OF LOCAL HISTORY. IN THIS PROPOSAL, THEY DESCRIBE A PATH TO ENGAGE INDIGENOUS AND HISPANIC COMMUNITY PARTNERS AS ADVISORS FOR ENHANCING THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE AND INCREASE INCLUSIVITY AT PADILLA BAY USING THREE CULTURALLY VALUABLE LENSES FOR LEARNING ABOUT THE NATURAL WORLD: LANGUAGE, ART, AND INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE.

THE HE'EIA NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE, KANE'OHE HI (HENERR) WAS DESIGNATED ON JANUARY 19, 2017. WITH PASSAGE OF THE COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT ACT OF 1972, THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALLY RECOGNIZED THE NATIONAL SIGNIFICANCE OF COASTAL RESOURCES AND
AUTHORIZED THE NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE SYSTEM (NERRS) ADMINISTERED BY NOAA. THE HENERR IS THE 29TH SITE TO BE DESIGNATED AS PART OF THE NERR SYSTEM. THE NERRS WORKS WITH EXISTING FEDERAL AND STATE AUTHORITIES TO ESTABLISH AND OPERATE RESEARCH RESERVES AND PROVIDE FOR THEIR LONG-TERM STEWARDSHIP. THE STATE OF HAWAI'I HAS
DESIGNATED THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI'I, HAWAI'I INSTITUTE OF MARINE BIOLOGY (HIMB) AS THE LEAD STATE AGENCY FOR THE RESERVE. THE HENERR MANAGEMENT PLAN DESCRIBES IN DETAIL THE RESERVE PROGRAMS AND OPERATIONS DURING THE FIVE-YEAR PERIOD EXTENDING FROM JULY 2017 TO
DECEMBER 2022. THIS PROPOSAL IS BASED UPON THAT MANAGEMENT PLAN AND COVERS THE PERIOD EXTENDING FROM JULY 2021 THROUGH DECEMBER 2022.
